paragraph.value:
As we do not want to test multiple systems on the final test set, we report the remaining ablations on the development set (AIDA-A), Table 3. We constructed a baseline which only relies on link statistics in Wikipedia as well as string similarity (we refereed to its scoring function as sc). It appears surprisingly strong, however, we still outperform it by [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,%] (see Table 3). When we use only global coherence (i.e. only second term in expression (1)) and drop any modeling of local context on the disambiguation stage, the performance drops very substantially (to [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,% F1], see Table 3). Without using local scores the disambiguation model appears to be even [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,] than our 'no-statisticaldisambiguation' baseline. It is also important to have an accurate global model: not using global attention results in a [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,%] drop in performance.

Given the unusual format and values for the performance metrics ("C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,"), it seems that they should be replaced with actual numerical percentages. However, based on your instruction, I have annotated the detected expressions as per their original text. Please ensure these placeholders are updated with correct numerical values if available.
